item.description: Tesla Inc. AI4 Will Be Capable Of Self-Driving On Monday, user @iliketeslas shared a post on the social media platform X, stating that the current AI4 chips are capable of running Unsupervised FSD without "better hardware." item.title: [INTC] Intel results to spotlight turnaround efforts as AI data centers boost chip demand
item.description: Intel shareholders are optimistic about the company's results like they have not been for many quarters, betting the turnaround CEO Lip-Bu Tan promised was taking root and that rapid data center build outs were fueling strong demand ​for its traditional server chips. A slew of high-profile investments engineered by Tan last year piqued investor interest in a stock that ‌had crashed in 2024 following years of management missteps, including a botched AI product roadmap that led to deep competitive losses and thousands of job cuts. Intel's stock gained 84% in 2025, ‌far outperforming the benchmark semiconductor index's 42% rise.

item.title: [AAPL] Treasury Yield Spike Can’t Be Ignored. Stocks Are Vulnerable to ‘Sell America’ Pressures.
item.description: The current turmoil in global bond markets, which has triggered a spike in U.S. Treasury yields and a record slump in Japan, could have big implications for stock markets heading into a crucial early stretch of the new year. President Donald Trump’s vow to take over Greenland “one way or the other,” as well as his new tariff threats on European allies and the ongoing pressure on Federal Reserve independence, has stoked a new phase of the so-called Sell America trade in bond markets that spilled over violently into stocks on the first day of the holiday-shortened week. The bond market slump Tuesday, which was accelerated by a looming fiscal crisis in Japan as the country heads toward a snap national election next month, lifted benchmark 10-year Treasury note yields just past 4.3%, the highest since August 2025.

item.title: [AAPL] Intel Stock Rises Again After Upgrades. Why Wall Street Is Warming to It.
item.description: Intel stock was gaining again early Wednesday ahead of the chip company’s earnings report. Intel shares were up 2.4% at $49.73 in premarket trading. As Barron’s has written, several Wall Street analysts have turned more positive on Intel stock in recent weeks, after the company unveiled new processors and comments from President Donald Trump praising CEO Lip-Bu Tan.

item.title: [AAPL] Amazon Investors Bet on AWS to Pull the Stock Out of Its Malaise
item.description: The optimism starts with demand for the Amazon Web Services cloud-computing business, which is positioned to benefit from the explosion of artificial intelligence technology. “An improvement in AWS should help materially in terms of the perception of the stock as being the relative loser in cloud,” said Pat Burton, a portfolio manager at Winslow Capital Management, who counts Amazon as one of his biggest overweights among the Magnificent Seven tech giants. Amazon shares were the worst performers among the Mag Seven in 2025, their seventh straight year trailing the group.

item.title: [AAPL] Netflix defends Warner Bros bid as shares drop on tepid results
item.description: Jan 21 (Reuters) - "YouTube is not just user-generated content and cat videos anymore," Netflix CEO Ted Sarandos said on Tuesday. Making a compelling case for why the streaming giant wanted Warner Bros Discovery's studio and streaming assets, Sarandos noted how tech giants such ​as Alphabet's YouTube had changed what television viewing meant and forced Netflix to change tack to keep up. Sarandos and his co-CEO Greg Peters spent a large portion of the post-earnings call talking effusively about how strong and complementary Warner Bros' services were, a sharp change from the long-held company credo: build, don't buy.

item.title: [AAPL] US futures edge higher and gold hits another record as markets swoon over Greenland dispute
item.description: Asian shares mostly extended their losses on Wednesday and gold prices hit a record high as concerns over U.S. President Donald Trump’s tariff threats on Greenland fueled unease among investors. U.S. futures rose after steep losses Tuesday on Wall Street. Gold prices crossed the $4,800 mark for the first time, gaining 1.7% as money flowed into assets considered to be safe havens at times of uncertainty.
